item.title: Algebra 2
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“Server-Unknown.Net, post:23, topic:302284”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=398601.msg2957929#msg2957929 date=1252962966]

Woops, I didn’t mean to put the first one up there :S… It’s the ones with two numbers on both sides that confuses me.

1/3x - 4/3 = -1/6x - 1
x - 4 = -1/2x - 3
3/2x = 1
x = 2/3

???
[/quote][quote author=T4_ link=topic=398601.msg2957913#msg2957913 date=1252962515]
This is basic algebra… with nice numbers.

1/3x = -x + 4
x = -3x + 12
4x = 12
x = 3

Did you really need assistance?
[/quote]

dude ur 17 years old, wrongly of you to say that, you say it like its the easiest thing in the world of math when it actually isn’t at all. Algebra is so different compared to the usual math you used in elementary, where the letters intervene with numbers. And the numbers are carried within the letter(s), just like in programming languages–which is why u really need to learn algebra(it’s also used for scientific situations too, which affect the brain in many ways). Did you know that a number of [the] people is considered basic algebra?[/quote]
L. Algebra II is easy shit.

Read full topic

item.title: Algebra 2
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Rictoo, post:8, topic:302284”]The way you wrote the questions was quite ambiguous.

In the first one for example, T4_ assumed the left side was (1/3)x, but I read it as 1/(3x) (which it is according to your notation). With 1/(3x) it becomes a second degree equation (solve using the quadratic formula).[/quote]
Sorry, was too lazy to be explicit on operation notation; especially since this is BASIC mathematics.

Read full topic

item.title: Algebra 2
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Rictoo, post:8, topic:302284”]The way you wrote the questions was quite ambiguous.

In the first one for example, T4_ assumed the left side was (1/3)x, but I read it as 1/(3x) (which it is according to your notation). With 1/(3x) it becomes a second degree equation (solve using the quadratic formula).[/quote]

Are you sure? In PEMDAS (Parenthesis, Exponantiation, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction) both multiplication/division and addition/subtraction are equal and therefore they are done from left to right.

Besides that, they aren’t really divisions, but fractions. Fractions are displayed with a fraction line, but they can’t be displayed that way here. So it’s best to put them between parenthesis too. But Starting up stated that 1/3 is a fraction, and not 1/3x, so Starting up has to clear things up.

Read full topic

item.title: Algebra 2
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

The way you wrote the questions was quite ambiguous.

In the first one for example, T4_ assumed the left side was (1/3)x, but I read it as 1/(3x) (which it is according to your notation). With 1/(3x) it becomes a second degree equation (solve using the quadratic formula).

Read full topic

How the fuck are you in algebra 2 and you can’t do this basic shit?

item.title: Algebra 2
item.dc:creator: @Starting_up Starting up ...
item.description:
@Starting_up wrote:

1/3x = -x + 4

-1/3x +1 = 3/2x - 1

2/3x - 9 = - 1/2x + 4

1/3x - 4/3 = -1/6x - 1

ex 1/3 is a fraction.

Read full topic
